   71 yo F w/ CAD, ischemic [**Numeric Identifier 5346**] (EF 10%) s/p [**Hospital1 **]-V ICD, atrial
   fibrillation, CKD, with past history of DVT and PE on Coumadin who was
   recently discharged from the CCU ([**11-6**]) for CHF exacerbation c/b
   C.diff infection, who is now being transferred from [**Hospital 108**] hospital
   for Septic shoulder joint (MRSA) and hypoxia, requiring intubation.
   # Respiratory Failure:  Patient developed worsening hypoxia as OSH
   requiring NRB and eventually intubation.   Patient has history of CHF
   with EF 10% which is the likely cause of her respiratory failure.  CXR
   yesterday with loss of volume on R side
 improved on subsequent CXR,
   suggesting clearing of mucous plug. Pt has sputum Cx with GPC in pairs,
   but no evidence of PNA on CXR.
   -- continue Lasix gtt
   -- goal I/Os even to net negative 500cc
   -- wean vent as tolerated, goal for extubation today
   -- cont Fentanyl/Versed
   -- wean Dopa for SBP>85
   -- hold Milrinone for now
   # Septic Joint:  Patient with +staph aureus in left shoulder.  Patient
   also had +hemarthrosis of left shoulder. Ortho performed aspiration of
   L shoulder joint [**2179-11-21**].
   - continue Vanc
   - f/u Vanc trough this AM
   - f/u ortho recs
 likely repeat aspiration tomorrow
   # Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive today for GPC in
   clusters/pairs, likely MRSA.
   - remove OSH PICC line
   - place L subclavian today
   - continue IV Vanc
   # CORONARIES: Patient with h/o CAD w/ right dominant system, mild
   instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent and occluded RCA.
   - cont ASA 81mg, Simva 20mg
   - on telemetry
   # PUMP: Patient with h/o ischemic [**Last Name (LF) 5346**], [**First Name3 (LF) 300**] 10%, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**].
   - strict I/Os
 goal even to negative 500cc
   - daily weights
   - diuresis as above
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o atrial fibrillation, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**], on coumadin.  Patient paced on [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**]
   obtain ECG to compare with previous ECG
   - cont home Amiodarone
   - hold dig, supratherapeutic level 2.6
   - hold coumadin for now for supratherapeutic INR
   - f/u INR
   .
   # Acute on CRF: Patient w/ baseline Cr 1.3-1.8, 2.4 on presentation.
   Likely related to CHF. FEUrea 35%.
   - monitor Cr
   .
   # H/o DVT/PE: Patient has h/o DVT/PE currently on coumadin and has a
   [**Location (un) **] filter in place.  Supratherapeutic INR, now improved to 3.3
   with FFP.
   - coumadin held for now
   - f/u INR
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue Levothyroxine.
   .
   # Allopurinol:  Patient on Allopurinol, unclear why. Right 3^rd MCP
   joint swelling may be related to gout, but shoulder tap shows
   pseudogout.
   # FEN: NPO, tube feeds, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # ACCESS: PICC
 to be replaced today with L subclavian triple lumen
   .
   # PROPHYLAXIS: supratherapeutic INR, coumadin held
   .
   # CODE: Full Code
   .

   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   Medical Decision Making
   Repeat chest x-ray demonstrates resolution of atalectasis and volume
   loss like due to resolution of a mucus plug. INR rose to a high of 11.2
   yesterday for which she received 5 mg SQ Vitamin K. Repeat INR is 3.3
   this am. MRSA grew in the left shoulder joint effusion and so
   antibiotics have been changed to IV Vancomycin. Ortho stopped by
   yesterday and aspirated/washed out the left shoulder. They felt it was
   not necessary to do a diagnostic tap on the right third finger
   erythema. BPs have been low in the last 24 hours and so low dose
   dopamine has been used and Milrinone held. This am   ABG looked good on
   PS 12 and 40% fIO2 and so we will reduce the sedation and check a RSBI
   followed by extubation if possible. Blood cultures are also positive
   for Gm pos cocci in clusters likely the same staph as in the shoulder.
   We will decrease her lasix drip today and aim for even to slightly
   negative fluid balance. Dr [**First Name (STitle) **] has been made aware of the patient's
   condition and will resume her care in the am tomorrow.
   I have discussed this plan with Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 11005**], [**Doctor Last Name 810**].
   Total time spent on patient care: 45 minutes of critical care time.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2179-11-22**] 01:35 PM ------

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the CCU for a CHF exacerbation and was readmitted to the ICU for septic shock and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient developed worsening hypoxia, requiring non-rebreather mask (NRB) and eventually intubation. The CXR shows clearing of mucous plug, suggesting that the patient's respiratory failure is likely related to her CHF.
* Septic joint: The patient has a positive culture for MRSA in her left shoulder joint, and an aspirate of the joint fluid showed GPC in pairs.
* Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA.
* Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of CAD with a right dominant system, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent, and occluded RCA.
* Pacing: The patient is paced on a BiV ICD.

The patient's current medications include:

* Vancomycin for MRSA
* Fentanyl and midazolam for sedation
* Dopamine for hypotension
* Lasix for fluid management
* Milrinone for cardiac support
* Coumadin for anticoagulation
* Allopurinol for gout
* Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 10.9
* Hct: 39.3
* Plt: 207
* Cr: 2.6
* TropT: 0.07
* TCO2: 25
* Glucose: 117
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 213 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.5 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.5 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* CXR: clearing of mucous plug in the right upper lung
* R hand xray: no convincing erosions in the 3rd MCP joint
* L shoulder xray: sclerosis and narrowing in the glenohumeral joint

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Lasix gtt for fluid management
* Wean vent as tolerated, goal for extubation today
* Continue Fentanyl and midazolam for sedation
* Wean dopamine for hypotension
* Hold Milrinone for now
* Continue Vancomycin for MRSA
* Repeat aspiration of the left shoulder joint tomorrow
* Monitor Cr levels
* Hold Coumadin for now for supratherapeutic INR
* Continue Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely related to her CHF, and there is a risk of worsening hypoxia and respiratory acidosis if not managed properly.
* Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures for MRSA and septic joint fluid raise concerns about the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and pacing device raises concerns about the possibility of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease and supratherapeutic INR raise concerns about the possibility of renal failure, which can be exacerbated by the patient's medications and underlying medical conditions.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of CHF and recent hospitalization raise concerns about the possibility of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea and vomiting.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition require close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the CCU for a CHF exacerbation caused by a C. difficile infection and was transferred to the ICU for septic shock and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is critical, with a fever of 101.2Â°F, tachycardia, and hypotension. She has a positive blood culture for MRSA and a joint aspirate showing GPC in pairs. Her respiratory status is unstable, with worsening hypoxia requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results indicate acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL, and electrolyte imbalances. Her hemoglobin level is 11.2 g/dL, and her platelet count is 207 K/uL.

The patient's imaging studies show signs of chronic kidney disease, with bilateral kidney calcifications and a left shoulder joint effusion.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Continued treatment with vancomycin for MRSA septicemia and joint infection.
2. Weaning of vasopressors and intubation as tolerated.
3. Monitoring of renal function and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Management of chronic kidney disease with strict fluid balance and electrolyte management.
5. Consideration of dialysis if the patient's renal function does not improve.
6. Continued treatment with fentanyl and midazolam for pain and sedation.
7. Monitoring of the patient's cardiac status, including echocardiogram and telemetry.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to ongoing MRSA infection.
2. Acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease progression.
3. Respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias and decreased cardiac output.
5. Electrolyte imbalances and acid-base disturbances.
6. Infection and sepsis related to the central line and other invasive devices.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical comorbidities and acute infections. Close monitoring and management of her condition are necessary to prevent complications and improve her chances of recovery.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of CAD, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, CKD, DVT, and PE. She was recently discharged from the CCU for CHF exacerbation and C. diff infection, and is now being transferred to the ICU for septic shoulder joint and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory Failure: The patient developed worsening hypoxia, requiring NRB and eventual intubation. CXR shows clearing of mucous plug, suggesting expectoration of a mucous plug with relief of volume loss.
* Septic Joint: The patient has a positive culture for MRSA in the left shoulder joint, and has a history of hemarthrosis of the left shoulder. Ortho tapped and washed out the L shoulder joint.
* Coronaries: The patient has a history of CAD with right dominant system, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent, and occluded RCA.
* Pump: The patient has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p BiV ICD, and is on coumadin.
* Rhythm: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, s/p BiV ICD, and is on coumadin.
* Acute on CRF: The patient has a baseline Cr of 1.3-1.8, and Cr of 2.4 on presentation, likely related to CHF.
* H/o DVT/PE: The patient has a history of DVT/PE, currently on coumadin, and has a filter in place.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient is on Levothyroxine.
* Allopurinol: The patient is on Allopurinol, unclear why, and may be related to gout.
* FEN: The patient is NPO, tube feeds, and replete lytes PRN.
* ACCESS: The patient has a PICC line.
* PROPHYLAXIS: The patient is on supratherapeutic INR, and coumadin is held.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Pneumonia: Given the patient's history of CHF and recent C. diff infection, pneumonia is a potential complication.
* Sepsis: The patient's positive culture for MRSA in the left shoulder joint and history of hemarthrosis of the left shoulder increase the risk of sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and requirement for intubation increase the risk of respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and atrial fibrillation increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock.
* Renal failure: The patient's baseline Cr of 1.3-1.8 and Cr of 2.4 on presentation increase the risk of renal failure.
* Bleeding complications: The patient's supratherapeutic INR and history of coumadin use increase the risk of bleeding complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure optimal care.

 71 yo F w/ CAD, ischemic [**Month/Day/Year 5346**] (EF 10%) s/p [**Hospital1 **]-V ICD, atrial
   fibrillation, CKD, with past history of DVT and PE on Coumadin who was
   recently discharged from the CCU ([**11-6**]) for CHF exacerbation c/b
   C.diff infection, who is now being transferred from [**Hospital 108**] hospital
   for Septic shoulder joint (MRSA) and hypoxia, requiring intubation.
   # Hypotension: low BP requiring pressor support: dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Etiology likely multifactorial shock from sepsis (MRSA
   bacteremia and septic shock) and cardiogenic with EF of 10%. On RV
   catheterization [**11-22**]; CVL > 17 suggesting that hypovolemia is not
   playing significant role in hypotension
   - wean dobutamine and dopamine to maintain MAP > 60
   - cont abx coverage with vancomycin
   - source control with joint aspiration/ washout
   - aggressive diuresis role with -1 to 2 L/day as tolerated by BP
   # Respiratory Failure:  Patient developed worsening hypoxia as OSH
   requiring NRB and eventually intubation.   Patient has history of CHF
   with EF 10% which is the likely cause of her respiratory failure.  CXR
   yesterday with loss of volume on R side
 improved on subsequent CXR,
   suggesting clearing of mucous plug. Pt has sputum Cx with GPC in pairs,
   but no evidence of PNA on CXR.  Saturating well on minimal vent
   settings with minimal sedatives
   -- wean vent as tolerated, goal for extubation today
   -- wean Fentanyl/Versed
   -- wean Dopa for SBP>85
   -- hold Milrinone for now
   # Septic Joint:  Patient with +staph aureus in left shoulder.  Patient
   also had +hemarthrosis of left shoulder. Ortho performed aspiration of
   L shoulder joint [**2179-11-21**].
   - continue Vanc
   - bedside aspiration planned for today
   - hold anticoagulation with warfarin pending plan for possible OR
   washout
   # Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive today for GPC in
   clusters/pairs, likely MRSA with likely source septic glenohumeral
   joint.  Other possible etiologies PNA (GPC in sputum), UTI, line
   infection.  Picc line placed at OSH replaced yesterday with central
   cordis
   - continue IV Vanc
   - cont daily surveillance cx until negative
   # CORONARIES: Patient with h/o CAD w/ right dominant system, mild
   instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent and occluded RCA.  No evidence
   of ischemic event precipitating cardiogenic shock
   - cont ASA 81mg, Simva 20mg
   - on telemetry
   # PUMP: Patient with h/o ischemic [**Last Name (LF) 5346**], [**First Name3 (LF) 300**] 10%, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**].  As above, exhibiting symptoms of cardiogenic
   shock with volume overload
   - strict I/Os
 goal even to negative 500cc

   - diuresis as above
   .

   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**], on coumadin.  Patient paced on [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**]
   obtain ECG to compare with previous ECG.  INR within therapeutic
   range.  Can resume as long as ortho has no plans to take pt to OR
   - cont home Amiodarone
   - hold dig, supratherapeutic level 2.6
   - f/u INR
   - consider resumption of coumadin 2mg daily
   .
   # Acute on CRF: Patient w/ baseline Cr 1.3-1.8, 2.4 on presentation.
   Likely related to CHF. FEUrea 35%.
   - monitor Cr
   .
   # H/o DVT/PE: Patient has h/o DVT/PE currently on coumadin and has a
   [**Location (un) **] filter in place.  Supratherapeutic INR, now improved to
   therapeutic range of 2.7.
   - coumadin held for now
   - f/u INR
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue Levothyroxine.
   .
   # Allopurinol:  Patient on Allopurinol, unclear why. Right 3^rd MCP
   joint swelling may be related to gout, but shoulder tap shows
   pseudogout.
   # FEN: NPO, tube feeds, replete lytes PRN
   .

 to be replaced today with L subclavian triple lumen
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the CCU for CHF exacerbation and C. difficile infection, but was readmitted due to septic shock, hypoxia, and septic joint. She is currently intubated and receiving pressor support with dopamine and dobutamine.

The patient has a septic joint with positive cultures for MRSA, and is being treated with vancomycin. She also has bacteremia with GPC in clusters/pairs, likely due to MRSA. The patient has a history of CAD with right dominant system, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent, and occluded RCA.

The patient is experiencing cardiogenic shock with volume overload, and is being treated with diuresis and strict I/Os. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is being paced.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to MRSA bacteremia and septic joint.
2. Cardiogenic shock due to ischemic cardiomyopathy and volume overload.
3. Respiratory failure due to CHF and hypoxia.
4. Acute kidney injury due to CHF and sepsis.
5. Hypothyroidism due to Levothyroxine therapy.
6. Gout or pseudogout due to Allopurinol therapy.
7. Deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism due to history of DVT/PE and current anticoagulation therapy.

Plan:

1. Continue vancomycin therapy for septic joint and bacteremia.
2. Wean dopamine and dobutamine to maintain MAP > 60.
3. Continue diuresis and strict I/Os to manage cardiogenic shock and volume overload.
4. Monitor Cr levels and adjust therapy as needed.
5. Continue Levothyroxine therapy for hypothyroidism.
6. Consider resuming Coumadin therapy for atrial fibrillation.
7. Monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.
8. Consider prophylactic antibiotics for potential line infections.
9. Monitor for signs of sepsis and septic shock, and adjust therapy as needed.
10. Consider extubation and weaning of ventilator support as tolerated.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the coronary care unit (CCU) for a heart failure exacerbation and was readmitted to the hospital for septic shock and hypoxia.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Respiratory failure: She requires mechanical ventilation due to worsening hypoxia and has a history of chronic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 10%.
2. Septic joint: She has a positive culture for Staphylococcus aureus in her left shoulder joint and has undergone aspiration of the joint.
3. Bacteremia: Her blood cultures are positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely due to MRSA.
4. Coronary artery disease: She has a history of coronary artery disease with mild instent restenosis of the left anterior descending artery and occluded right coronary artery.
5. Cardiac rhythm: She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is paced on a bi-ventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).
6. Acute on chronic kidney disease: Her baseline creatinine levels are 1.3-1.8 mg/dL, and her current creatinine level is 2.4 mg/dL.
7. Hypothyroidism: She is taking levothyroxine.
8. Allopurinol: She is taking allopurinol, but the reason for this medication is unclear, and her right third metacarpophalangeal joint swelling may be related to gout or pseudogout.

The patient's current medications include:

* Dobutamine
* Dopamine
* Lasix
* Protonix
* Simvastatin
* Levothyroxine
* Multivitamin
* Cholestyramine
* Allopurinol
* Amiodarone
* ASA
* Vancomycin
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Docusate
* Senna

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.0 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 34.3%
* Platelets: 169 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 35 mg/dL
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 213 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: Elderly female, intubated, sedated, opens eyes to verbal stimuli
* HEENT: Normal
* Neck: Supple with jugular venous pressure to the angle of the jaw
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2, II/VI systolic murmur, regular rhythm
* Lungs: Clear to auscultation
* Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, with ascites and a fluid wave
* Extremities: Positive pedal edema, dopplerable pedal pulses, left shoulder with a dressing and right metacarpophalangeal joint with blanching erythema and edema
* Skin: Dry

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: She may develop further respiratory failure due to her chronic heart failure and septic shock.
2. Sepsis: She may develop sepsis due to her bacteremia and septic joint.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: She may develop cardiac arrhythmias due to her atrial fibrillation and paced rhythm.
4. Acute kidney injury: She may develop acute kidney injury due to her septic shock and acute on chronic kidney disease.
5. Deep vein thrombosis: She may develop deep vein thrombosis due to her history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and ongoing medical issues, it is essential to closely monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, acute coagulopathy, and acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure. She has a history of chronic pain and impaired skin integrity. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume set at 450 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. Her blood pressure is being maintained with dopamine and dobutamine infusions, and she is receiving lasix for fluid management.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and increased lactate levels. Her coagulation profile is abnormal, with an international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.7. Her cardiac enzymes are elevated, with a troponin-T level of 0.07 ng/mL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, liver failure, or respiratory failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of invasive procedures.
4. Heart failure: The patient's acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure may worsen, leading to decreased cardiac output, increased morbidity, and mortality.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of skin breakdown, infection, and sepsis.
6. Pain control: The patient's chronic pain may not be adequately managed, leading to discomfort, distress, and potential complications.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may lead to increased risk of cardiac failure, respiratory failure, and electrolyte imbalances.
8. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated lactate levels may indicate renal dysfunction, which may worsen if not addressed promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely.
2. Adjust the patient's fluid management and vasopressor therapy as needed to maintain adequate blood pressure and perfusion.
3. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen to treat the suspected sepsis.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
5. Consider adding a coagulation factor to the patient's regimen to address the coagulopathy.
6. Continue to manage the patient's pain with a multimodal approach, including analgesics, anxiolytics, and non-pharmacological interventions.
7. Monitor the patient's skin integrity closely and consider implementing measures to prevent skin breakdown.
8. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to address the patient's potential renal dysfunction.

   Assessment and Plan
 71 yo F w/ CAD, ischemic [**Month/Day/Year 5346**] (EF 10%) s/p [**Hospital1 **]-V ICD, atrial
   fibrillation, CKD, with past history of DVT and PE on Coumadin who was
   recently discharged from the CCU ([**11-6**]) for CHF exacerbation c/b
   C.diff infection, who is now being transferred from [**Hospital 108**] hospital
   for Septic shoulder joint (MRSA) and hypoxia, requiring intubation.
   # Hypotension: low BP requiring pressor support: dopamine and
   dobutamine.  Etiology likely multifactorial shock from sepsis (MRSA
   bacteremia and septic shock) and cardiogenic with EF of 10%. On RV
   catheterization [**11-22**]; CVL > 17 suggesting that hypovolemia is not
   playing significant role in hypotension
   - wean dobutamine and dopamine to maintain MAP > 60
   - cont abx coverage with vancomycin
   - source control with joint aspiration/ washout
   - aggressive diuresis role with -1 to 2 L/day as tolerated by BP
   # Respiratory Failure:  Patient developed worsening hypoxia as OSH
   requiring NRB and eventually intubation.   Patient has history of CHF
   with EF 10% which is the likely cause of her respiratory failure.  CXR
   yesterday with loss of volume on R side
 improved on subsequent CXR,
   suggesting clearing of mucous plug. Pt has sputum Cx with GPC in pairs,
   but no evidence of PNA on CXR.  Saturating well on minimal vent
   settings with minimal sedatives
   -- wean vent as tolerated, goal for extubation today
   -- wean Fentanyl/Versed
   -- hold Milrinone for now
   # Septic Joint:  Patient with +staph aureus in left shoulder.  Patient
   also had +hemarthrosis of left shoulder. Ortho performed aspiration of
   L shoulder joint [**2179-11-21**].
   - continue Vanc
   - bedside aspiration planned for today
   - hold anticoagulation with warfarin pending plan for possible OR
   washout
   # Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive today for GPC in
   clusters/pairs, likely MRSA with likely source septic glenohumeral
   joint.  Other possible etiologies PNA (GPC in sputum), UTI, line
   infection.  Picc line placed at OSH replaced yesterday with central
   cordis
   - continue IV Vanc
   - cont daily surveillance cx until negative
   # CORONARIES: Patient with h/o CAD w/ right dominant system, mild
   instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent and occluded RCA.  No evidence
   of ischemic event precipitating cardiogenic shock
   - cont ASA 81mg, Simva 20mg
   - on telemetry
   # PUMP: Patient with h/o ischemic [**Last Name (LF) 5346**], [**First Name3 (LF) 300**] 10%, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**].  As above, exhibiting symptoms of cardiogenic
   shock with volume overload
   - strict I/Os  with aggressive diuresis as tolerated by BP
   - daily weights
   - consider restarting Lasix if output diminishes
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o atrial fibrillation, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**], on coumadin.  Patient paced on [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**]
   obtain ECG to compare with previous ECG.  INR within therapeutic
   range.  Can resume as long as ortho has no plans to take pt to OR
   - cont home Amiodarone
   - hold dig, supratherapeutic level 2.6
   - f/u INR
   -start heparin gtt pending stabilization of medical condition
   .
   # Acute on CRF: Patient w/ baseline Cr 1.3-1.8, 2.4 on presentation.
   Likely related to CHF. FEUrea 35%.
   - monitor Cr
   .
   # H/o DVT/PE: Patient has h/o DVT/PE currently on coumadin and has a
   [**Location (un) **] filter in place.  Supratherapeutic INR, now improved to
   therapeutic range of 2.7.
   - coumadin held for now
   - start heparin gtt
   - f/u INR
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue Levothyroxine.
   .
   # Allopurinol:  Patient on Allopurinol, unclear why. Right 3^rd MCP
   joint swelling may be related to gout, but shoulder tap shows
   pseudogout.
   # FEN: NPO, tube feeds, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # ACCESS: PICC
 to be replaced today with L subclavian triple lumen
   .
   # PROPHYLAXIS: supratherapeutic INR, coumadin held
   .
   # CODE: Full Code
   .
   # DISPO: CCU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of CAD, ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 10%), atrial fibrillation, CKD, DVT, and PE. She was recently discharged from the CCU for CHF exacerbation caused by C. difficile infection and was transferred to the ICU for septic shock and hypoxia due to MRSA bacteremia and septic shock. She has a central line infection, bacteremia, and a septic joint in her left shoulder. She is being treated with vancomycin, dobutamine, and dopamine to maintain MAP > 60, and is receiving aggressive diuresis to manage fluid overload.

The patient has a complex medical history, including CAD, cardiogenic shock, and CHF, which is likely contributing to her respiratory failure. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is paced, and has a BiV ICD in place. She also has a history of DVT and PE, and has a filter in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's EF is only 10%, which makes her susceptible to cardiogenic shock. Her hypotension and low cardiac output are likely contributing to her shock state.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a septic joint and bacteremia, which increases her risk of sepsis and septic shock.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of CHF and is currently experiencing respiratory failure, which may worsen if not managed properly.
4. Central line infection: The patient has a central line infection, which may lead to bacteremia and septic shock if not treated promptly.
5. Fluid overload: The patient has fluid overload, which may worsen her respiratory failure and increase her risk of cardiogenic shock.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient is taking levothyroxine for hypothyroidism, but her thyroid function should be closely monitored to ensure that it is within normal ranges.
7. Gout: The patient has a history of gout, which may be contributing to her joint pain and swelling.
8. Pseudogout: The patient has pseudogout in her right third MCP joint, which may be contributing to her joint pain and swelling.

Plan:

1. Continue vancomycin and dobutamine to manage septic shock and cardiogenic shock.
2. Aggressively manage fluid overload with diuresis and close monitoring of I/Os.
3. Wean dobutamine and dopamine to maintain MAP > 60.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac function closely to ensure that her cardiogenic shock is managed properly.
5. Monitor the patient's respiratory function closely to ensure that her respiratory failure is managed properly.
6. Continue antibiotics to treat the patient's central line infection and bacteremia.
7. Monitor the patient's thyroid function closely to ensure that it is within normal ranges.
8. Consider restarting lasix if the patient's output diminishes.
9. Hold anticoagulation with warfarin pending plan for possible OR washout.
10. Start heparin gtt pending stabilization of medical condition.
11. Continue Fentanyl and Versed to manage pain and anxiety.
12. Monitor the patient's WBC count and platelet count to ensure that they are within normal ranges.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and past history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the CCU for CHF exacerbation and was readmitted to the ICU for septic shock and hypoxia. She has a septic joint in her left shoulder, and her blood cultures are positive for MRSA. She is intubated and on pressor support with dopamine and dobutamine.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Hypotension: low blood pressure requiring pressor support with dopamine and dobutamine.
* Respiratory failure: intubated and on minimal vent settings with minimal sedatives.
* Septic joint: +staph aureus in left shoulder, with planned bedside aspiration today.
* Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA.
* Coronaries: patient with history of CAD, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent, and occluded RCA.
* Pump: patient with history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p BiV ICD, exhibiting symptoms of cardiogenic shock with volume overload.
* Rhythm: patient paced on Coumadin, with INR within therapeutic range.
* Acute on CRF: patient with baseline Cr 1.3-1.8, currently 2.4, likely related to CHF.
* H/o DVT/PE: patient with history of DVT/PE, currently on Coumadin, with a filter in place.
* Hypothyroidism: patient on Levothyroxine.
* Allopurinol: patient on Allopurinol, unclear why.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, coagulopathy, heart failure, and impaired skin integrity. They have a history of chronic pain and are currently experiencing acute pain. The patient is mechanically ventilated and has a Swan-Ganz catheter in place. They have been receiving vasopressors, including dopamine and dobutamine, to maintain blood pressure and cardiac output.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to increased oxygen requirements and potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding and potentially life-threatening hemorrhage.
4. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure may worsen, leading to decreased cardiac output and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may worsen, leading to increased risk of infection and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Vasopressor dependence: The patient's dependence on vasopressors may worsen, leading to potential cardiovascular complications.
7. Catheter-related complications: The patient's Swan-Ganz catheter may become infected or cause bleeding, leading to potentially life-threatening complications.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional deficiencies may worsen, leading to potential complications such as muscle wasting and impaired wound healing.
9. Glycemic control: The patient's glycemic control may worsen, leading to potential complications such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
10. Line-related complications: The patient's lines, including the arterial line and central venous catheter, may become infected or cause bleeding, leading to potentially life-threatening complications.

 71 yo F w/ CAD, ischemic [**Month/Day (4) 5346**] (EF 10%) s/p [**Hospital1 **]-V ICD, atrial

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including CAD, ischemic cardiomyopathy, CKD, DVT, and PE. She was recently discharged from the CCU for CHF exacerbation and was readmitted to the ICU for septic shock, hypoxia, and a septic shoulder joint.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hypotension: The patient is experiencing hypotension, which is likely multifactorial, including sepsis, cardiogenic shock, and EF of 10%. She is receiving pressor support with dopamine and dobutamine.
* Respiratory Failure: The patient developed worsening hypoxia, requiring intubation. She has a history of CHF with EF 10%, which is likely the cause of her respiratory failure.
* Septic Joint: The patient has a positive culture for MRSA in her left shoulder joint, and she has also had hemarthrosis of the left shoulder.
* Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA, with a likely source of septic glenohumeral joint.
* Coronaries: The patient has a history of CAD with right dominant system, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent, and occluded RCA.
* Pump: The patient has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy with EF 10%, and she is exhibiting symptoms of cardiogenic shock with volume overload.
* Rhythm: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and she is paced on a BiV ICD.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.0
* Hct: 34.3
* Plt: 169
* Cr: 2.6
* TCO2: 28
* Glucose: 117
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 27.8/150.0/2.7, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T: 15//0.07, ALT / AST: 8-30, Alk Phos / T Bili: 112/1.9, Lactic Acid: 1.0 mmol/L, Albumin: 3.5 g/dL, LDH: 213 IU/L, Ca++: 8.6 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL, PO4: 3.2 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: Persistent enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with retrocardiac opacification, suggesting the possibility of underlying cardiomyopathy or pericardial effusion.
* ECHO: No valvular vegetation or wire-associated vegetation, but there is a probable left atrial appendage thrombus with spontaneous echo contrast also identified within the body of the left atrial appendage. Mild mitral regurgitation, at least moderate tricuspid regurgitation, and severe biventricular systolic dysfunction.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning dobutamine and dopamine to maintain MAP > 60
* Continuing antibiotic coverage with vancomycin
* Source control with joint aspiration/washout
* Aggressive diuresis with -1 to 2 L/day as tolerated by BP
* Weaning vent as tolerated, goal for extubation today
* Weaning Fentanyl/Versed
* Holding Milrinone for now
* Continuing IV Vanc
* Cont daily surveillance cx until negative
* Cont ASA 81mg, Simva 20mg
* On telemetry
* Strict I/Os with aggressive diuresis as tolerated by BP
* Daily weights
* Considering restarting Lasix if output diminishes
* Cont home Amiodarone
* Holding dig, supratherapeutic level 2.6
* F/u INR
* Start heparin gtt pending stabilization of medical condition
* Monitor Cr
* Start heparin gtt
* F/u INR
* Continue Levothyroxine
* Unclear why patient is on Allopurinol, but right 3^rd MCP joint swelling may be related to gout, but shoulder tap shows pseudogout.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further deterioration of cardiogenic shock
* Development of septic shock
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Bacteremia
* Septic joint
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypothyroidism
* Allopurinol-related complications (e.g., gout, pseudogout)
* DVT/PE
* CHF exacerbation
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 10%, and a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the coronary care unit (CCU) for a heart failure exacerbation caused by a Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection and was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for septic shock and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96%.
* Cardiovascular: hypotensive, with a blood pressure of 79/50 mmHg, and requiring pressor support with dopamine and dobutamine. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is paced.
* Renal: oliguric, with a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL, and requiring diuretic therapy.
* Hematological: anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 11.8 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 169 K/uL.
* Infectious: septic shock caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia, with positive blood cultures and a positive joint aspirate.
* Musculoskeletal: septic arthritis of the left shoulder, with a positive joint aspirate and a positive hemarthrosis.

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Antibiotic therapy with vancomycin to treat MRSA bacteremia and septic arthritis.
* Source control with joint aspiration and washout.
* Aggressive diuresis to manage fluid overload.
* Weaning of pressor support and mechanical ventilation as tolerated.
* Monitoring of renal function and adjusting diuretic therapy as necessary.
* Monitoring of blood cultures and joint aspirates to ensure clearance of infection.
* Consideration of surgical intervention for possible hip tap and washout.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued septic shock and organ dysfunction.
* Pneumonia or other secondary infections.
* Renal failure and need for dialysis.
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Neurological complications, such as sepsis-related encephalopathy.
* Wound complications, such as infection or dehiscence.
* Hematological complications, such as bleeding or thrombocytopenia.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and her disposition is currently in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly female who has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, acute coagulopathy, heart failure, and impaired skin integrity. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9Â°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 79/50 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes a nasal cannula with 50% FiO2, and the ventilator mode is set to PSV/SBT with a tidal volume of 450 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated lactate level, and elevated troponin-T level, which suggests ongoing sepsis and cardiac injury. The patient's coagulation profile shows prolonged PT and PTT, which suggests coagulopathy.

The patient's physical examination reveals pedal edema, dry skin, and blanching erythema and edema on the right MCP joint. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, and the patient's extremities are warm and well-perfused.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's ongoing sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and cardiac failure.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's prolonged PT and PTT can lead to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, hematuria, and epistaxis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if the patient's ventilation settings are not optimized, leading to hypercapnia and hypoxemia.
4. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure can worsen if the patient's cardiac function is not optimized, leading to increased congestion and edema.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity can lead to skin breakdown, including pressure ulcers and decubitus ulcers.
6. Pain control: The patient's acute and chronic pain can worsen if not adequately managed, leading to increased anxiety, agitation, and decreased mobility.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that the patient continue to receive aggressive treatment for sepsis, including antibiotics and source control. The patient's coagulopathy should be managed with fresh frozen plasma and platelet transfusions as necessary. The patient's respiratory failure should be managed with optimized ventilation settings, and the patient's heart failure should be managed with diuretics and vasodilators as necessary. The patient's impaired skin integrity should be managed with pressure ulcer prevention measures, and the patient's pain control should be managed with multimodal analgesia.

Summary:

The patient is a 71.5 kg male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of sepsis without organ dysfunction. The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, and recent lab results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating possible myocardial infarction. The patient is currently on heparin sodium infusion and has a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. The patient has been experiencing multiple PVCs and has had dopamin turned down. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9Â°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 79/50 mmHg.

The patient has a history of orthopedic issues, including a possible hip tap, and has been experiencing pain. The patient has been on multiple medications, including vancomycin, fentanyl, and midazolam.

The patient's lab results show elevated WBC count, decreased Hct, and elevated CR. The patient's glucose level is 117 mg/dL, and their albumin level is 3.5 g/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis is not improving, and there is a risk of further progression, leading to organ dysfunction and potential mortality.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's thrombus in the left atrial appendage and elevated troponin-T levels suggest a high risk of bleeding complications.
3. Heart failure: The patient's acute heart failure on chronic heart failure may worsen, leading to further cardiac complications.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory complications.
5. Pain control: The patient's acute and chronic pain may not be adequately controlled, leading to further complications.
6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may worsen, leading to further complications.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be adequate, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's antibiotic regimen based on the sensitivities of the cultured bacteria.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulation profile and adjust therapy accordingly.
4. Consider further cardiac testing, such as an echocardiogram, to assess the patient's cardiac function.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory function and adjust therapy accordingly.
6. Consider further pain management options, such as epidural anesthesia, to control the patient's pain.
7. Monitor the patient's skin integrity closely and consider further interventions, such as wound care, to prevent further complications.

 71 yo F w/ CAD, ischemic [**Month/Day (4) 5346**] (EF 10%) s/p [**Hospital1 **]-V ICD, atrial

   and hypoxia, requiring intubation.
   # Hypotension: low BP requiring pressor support with dopamine (weaned
   off dobutamine).  Etiology likely multifactorial shock from sepsis
   (MRSA bacteremia and septic shoulder) and cardiogenic with EF of 10%.

   playing significant role in hypotension
   - wean dopamine to maintain adequate end organ perfusion

   - aggressive diuresis role with -1 to 2 L/day as tolerated by BP

   also had +hemarthrosis of left shoulder. Ortho performed aspiration of
   L shoulder joint [**2179-11-21**].
   - continue Vanc
   - arthoscopy of left shoulder, arthroscopy of right MCP and left hip
   planned for today
   - PO vitamin K for reversal of INR, hold heparin gtt at 2am tomorrow
   # Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive today for GPC in
   clusters/pairs, likely MRSA with likely source septic glenohumeral
   joint.  No evidence of endocarditis on TEE yesterday.  Other possible
   etiologies PNA (GPC in sputum), UTI, line infection.  Picc line placed
   at OSH replaced yesterday with central cordis
   - continue IV Vanc

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the cardiac care unit (CCU) for congestive heart failure exacerbation and Clostridium difficile infection. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with septic shock due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia and septic shoulder joint. She has a pacemaker and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and she is requiring pressor support with dopamine.
* Septic joint: The patient has a septic left shoulder joint with MRSA bacteremia and hemarthrosis.
* Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for MRSA, likely from the septic joint.
* Coronaries: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with mild instent restenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery and occluded right coronary artery (RCA).
* Pump: The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is 10%, and she is experiencing cardiogenic shock.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure due to mucus plugging and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
* Rhythm: The patient is paced and has a history of atrial fibrillation.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's serum creatinine is elevated, likely due to chronic kidney disease.
* History of deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism: The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and is currently on heparin therapy.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient is taking levothyroxine for hypothyroidism.
* Allopurinol: The patient is taking allopurinol, but the reason is unclear.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to MRSA bacteremia and septic joint
* Cardiogenic shock due to cardiomyopathy and LVEF of 10%
* Respiratory failure due to mucus plugging and underlying COPD
* Acute kidney injury due to sepsis and cardiogenic shock
* Deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism due to immobility and central venous catheter
* Hypothyroidism exacerbation due to chronic kidney disease
* Gout flare due to allopurinol therapy

Plan:

* Continue antibiotics and source control measures for septic joint and bacteremia
* Wean dopamine and monitor for signs of cardiogenic shock
* Aggressively diurese to manage volume overload and hypertension
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and adjust oxygen therapy as necessary
* Monitor for signs of acute kidney injury and adjust fluid management and diuretic therapy as necessary
* Monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary
* Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism exacerbation and adjust levothyroxine therapy as necessary
* Monitor for signs of gout flare and adjust allopurinol therapy as necessary
* Plan for elective intubation for procedure tomorrow
* Plan for surgical intervention tomorrow

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of CAD, ischemic heart failure, and chronic kidney disease, who was recently discharged from the CCU for CHF exacerbation. She was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, hypoxia, and bacteremia caused by MRSA. She has a septic left shoulder joint and hip, and a possible left atrial appendage thrombus. She is currently intubated and receiving pressor support with dopamine. Her cardiac function is severely impaired, and she has mild mitral regurgitation and moderate tricuspid regurgitation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.9Â°C (100.2Â°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 79/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 96%
* WBC: 8.0
* Hct: 34.3%
* Platelet count: 169
* Creatinine: 2.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 117 mg/dL

The patient's labs and radiology reports show:

* Blood cultures positive for MRSA
* CXR shows persistent enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with retrocardiac opacification
* ECHO shows a probable left atrial appendage thrombus with spontaneous echo contrast
* Mild mitral regurgitation and moderate tricuspid regurgitation

The patient's plan is:

* To continue antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy
* To perform arthroscopy of the left shoulder, right MCP joint, and left hip
* To continue pressor support with dopamine and aggressive diuresis
* To monitor the patient's cardiac function and renal function
* To consider restarting Lasix if output diminishes
* To wean oxygen therapy as tolerated
* To consider elective intubation for the procedure tomorrow

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Hypothyroidism
* Allopurinol toxicity
* Gout
* Pseudogout
* Thrombocytopenia
* Anemia
* Hypocalcemia
* Hyperkalemia
* Hyperphosphatemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hypoproteinemia

Note: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and her respiratory and renal function are also compromised. She is at risk for further complications, such as septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and respiratory failure. Close monitoring and aggressive treatment are necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, deep vein thrombosis, and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the CCU for a heart failure exacerbation caused by a Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection and was readmitted to the ICU with septic shock, hypoxia, and bacteremia.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, requiring pressor support with dopamine. The etiology is likely multifactorial, including sepsis, cardiogenic shock, and hypovolemia.
2. Septic joint: The patient has a septic shoulder joint with MRSA bacteremia and hemarthrosis, which requires source control with left shoulder and hip washout/aspiration.
3. Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA, with a possible source of septic glenohumeral joint.
4. Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease with a right dominant system, mild instent re-stenois of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, and occluded right coronary artery (RCA).
5. Cardiogenic shock: The patient has a history of cardiogenic shock with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 10%, which may be contributing to her hypotension.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to mucus plugging and underlying chronic heart failure.
7. Rhythm disturbance: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently paced.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiogenic shock and hypotension may lead to cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and septic joint may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction.
4. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease and hypotension may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or failure.
5. Thrombotic events: The patient's history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism may increase her risk for thrombotic events, such as pulmonary embolism or stroke.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents may increase her risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotic therapy: Vancomycin will be continued to cover MRSA bacteremia.
2. Source control: Left shoulder and hip washout/aspiration will be performed to control the septic joint.
3. Pressor support: Dopamine will be weaned to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion.
4. Diuresis: Aggressive diuresis will be attempted to improve blood pressure and reduce fluid overload.
5. Cardiovascular support: Simvastatin will be continued to manage hyperlipidemia, and ASA will be held pending surgical intervention.
6. Respiratory support: Oxygen therapy will be continued, and elective intubation will be performed for the procedure tomorrow.
7. Rhythm management: The patient's rhythm will be monitored, and Amiodarone will be continued to manage atrial fibrillation.

In conclusion, the patient's complex medical conditions and treatment plan require close monitoring and management to prevent potential medical complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, cardiogenic shock, chronic kidney disease, and a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the coronary care unit (CCU) for a heart failure exacerbation caused by a Clostridioides difficile infection.

The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with septic shock, septic arthritis of the left shoulder and right metacarpophalangeal joint, and bacteremia. She was intubated and required pressor support with dopamine to maintain adequate blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with an elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate acid. Her cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating cardiac damage. Her electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Antibiotic coverage with vancomycin to treat MRSA bacteremia and septic arthritis.
2. Source control with washout of the left shoulder and right metacarpophalangeal joint, and aspiration of the left hip.
3. Cardiovascular support with dobutamine to maintain adequate blood pressure and cardiac output.
4. Fluid management to prevent hypovolemia and hypervolemia.
5. Respiratory support with oxygen therapy and weaning of mechanical ventilation.
6. Antiarrhythmic therapy with amiodarone to control atrial fibrillation.
7. Anticoagulation therapy with heparin to prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
8. Monitoring of creatinine levels to prevent acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Septic shock and septic organ failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Renal failure and acute kidney injury.
5. Coagulopathy and bleeding.
6. Infection of the central line and other catheters.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
8. Neurological complications, such as seizures and stroke.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent and manage potential complications.

* The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of cardiomyopathy (EF 10%), atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a recent discharge from the CCU for CHF exacerbation.
* She was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, hypoxia, and septic arthritis in her left shoulder and right MCP joint.
* Laboratory results show elevated inflammatory markers, including WBC count, CRP, and ESR.
* The patient has received multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin, and has been treated with dopamine for hypotension.
* She has undergone washout and aspiration of her left shoulder and right MCP joint, and has been scheduled for further surgical intervention.
* The patient has a history of DVT and PE, and is currently on heparin gtt.
* She has a central cordis line, and has been treated with dobutamine for cardiogenic shock.
* The patient's respiratory status has improved, and she is currently extubated and maintaining adequate saturation on nasal cannula oxygen.
* Her cardiac rhythm is currently paced, and she is receiving antiarrhythmic therapy with amiodarone.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to the ongoing infection in her joints and potential bacteremia.
* Cardiac complications, including cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac failure, given her history of cardiomyopathy and atrial fibrillation.
* Respiratory complications, including pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and respiratory failure, given her history of CHF and recent respiratory failure.
* Renal complications, including acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease progression, given her history of kidney disease and recent electrolyte imbalance.
* Hematological complications, including bleeding and coagulopathy, given her history of DVT and PE and current anticoagulation therapy.
* Skin and soft tissue complications, including wound infections and sepsis, given the ongoing infection in her joints.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via a nasal cannula.

The patient's neurological status is impaired, with decreased peripheral vascular pulses and impaired skin integrity.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and chronic liver disease. The patient has a history of antibiotic use, including vancomycin, and has developed an allergy to gentamicin.

   Assessment and Plan
   71 yo F w/ CAD, ischemic [**Month/Year (2) 5346**] (EF 10%) s/p [**Hospital1 **]-V ICD, atrial
   fibrillation, CKD, with past history of DVT and PE on Coumadin who was
   recently discharged from the CCU ([**11-6**]) for CHF exacerbation c/b
   C.diff infection, admitted from OSH with septic shoulder joint (MRSA)
   and hypoxia, requiring intubation.
   # Hypotension: low BP requiring pressor support with dopamine (weaned
   off dobutamine).  Etiology likely multifactorial shock from sepsis
   (MRSA bacteremia and septic shoulder) and cardiogenic with EF of 10%.
   On RV catheterization [**11-22**]; CVL > 17 suggesting that hypovolemia is not
   playing significant role in hypotension
   - wean dopamine to maintain adequate end organ perfusion
   - cont abx coverage with vancomycin 1gm q 48hrs
   - source control with left shoulder/ hip washout/ aspiration
   - aggressive diuresis role with -1 to 2 L/day as tolerated by BP
   # Septic Joint:  Patient with +staph aureus in left shoulder.  Patient
   also had +hemarthrosis of left shoulder. Ortho performed aspiration of
   L shoulder joint [**2179-11-21**].
   - continue Vanc
   - arthoscopy of left shoulder, arthroscopy of right MCP and left hip
   planned for today
   - PO vitamin K for reversal of INR, hold heparin gtt at 2am tomorrow
   # Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive today for GPC in
   clusters/pairs, likely MRSA with likely source septic glenohumeral
   joint.  No evidence of endocarditis on TEE yesterday.  Other possible
   etiologies PNA (GPC in sputum), UTI, line infection.  Picc line placed
   at OSH replaced yesterday with central cordis
   - continue IV Vanc
   - cont daily surveillance cx until negative
   # CORONARIES: Patient with h/o CAD w/ right dominant system, mild
   instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent and occluded RCA.  No evidence
   of ischemic event precipitating cardiogenic shock
   - con Simva 20mg
   - on telemetry
   - hold ASA pending surgical intervention tomorrow
   # PUMP: Patient with h/o ischemic [**Last Name (LF) 5346**], [**First Name3 (LF) 300**] 10%, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**].  As above, admitted with  symptoms of
   cardiogenic shock with volume overload .  Currently autodiuresing
   - strict I/Os  with aggressive diuresis as tolerated by BP
   - daily weights
   - consider restarting Lasix if output diminishes
   # Respiratory Failure:  Patient currently extubated and maintaining
   adequate saturation on RA.  Respiratory failure likely secondary to
   mucus plugging and underlying CHF. Pt has sputum Cx with GPC in pairs,
   but no evidence of PNA on CXR.
   - wean O2 as tolerated
   - elective intubation for procedure tomorrow
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o atrial fibrillation, s/p BiV ICD ([**Company 2375**]
   Concerto C154DWK) [**12-24**], on coumadin.  Patient paced on [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**]
   obtain ECG to compare with previous ECG. Intra-atrial thrombus on TEE,
   on heparin gtt
   - cont home Amiodarone
   - hold dig, supratherapeutic level 2.6
   - reverse INR with vitamin K pending surgical intervention tomorrow
   -hold heparin gtt at 2 am tomorrow am.
   # Acute on CRF: Patient w/ baseline Cr 1.3-1.8, 2.4 on presentation.
   Likely related to CHF. FEUrea 35%.
   - monitor Cr
   .
   # H/o DVT/PE: Patient has h/o DVT/PE currently on heparin gtt and has a
   [**Location (un) **] filter in place.  Supratherapeutic INR, now improved to
   therapeutic range of 2.8.
   - reverse INR with vitamin k x 1
   - start heparin gtt, hold tomorrow prior to OR
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue Levothyroxine.
   .
   # Allopurinol:  Patient on Allopurinol, unclear why. Right 3^rd MCP
   joint swelling may be related to gout, but shoulder tap shows
   pseudogout.
   # FEN: NPO after midnight, replete lytes PRN
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of CAD, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, CKD, and DVT/PE, admitted to the ICU for septic shock, septic joint, and bacteremia. She has a left shoulder septic joint with MRSA and is scheduled for arthroscopy and aspiration tomorrow. She has a central cordis line, and her blood cultures are positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA. She has a history of DVT/PE and is currently on heparin gtt.

Current status:

* Hypotension: low BP requiring pressor support with dopamine
* Septic joint: patient with +staph aureus in left shoulder, with aspiration planned for tomorrow
* Bacteremia: OSH blood cultures positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA
* Coronaries: patient with h/o CAD, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent and occluded RCA
* PUMP: patient with h/o ischemic cardiomyopathy, s/p BiV ICD, with symptoms of cardiogenic shock with volume overload
* Respiratory Failure: patient currently extubated and maintaining adequate saturation on RA
* RHYTHM: patient with h/o atrial fibrillation, s/p BiV ICD, on coumadin
* Acute on CRF: patient with baseline Cr 1.3-1.8, 2.4 on presentation
* H/o DVT/PE: patient with h/o DVT/PE, currently on heparin gtt and has a [**Location (un) **] filter in place

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: patient's EF is 10%, and she has a history of cardiomyopathy, which increases the risk of cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: patient has septic shock, septic joint, and bacteremia, which increases the risk of sepsis and septic shock.
3. Respiratory failure: patient has a history of CHF and is currently extubated, which increases the risk of respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: patient has CKD and is currently on hemodialysis, which increases the risk of renal failure.
5. Bleeding: patient is on heparin gtt and has a central cordis line, which increases the risk of bleeding.
6. Infection: patient has a septic joint and bacteremia, which increases the risk of infection.
7. Hypothyroidism: patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may require monitoring and treatment.
8. Gout: patient has a history of gout, which may require treatment and monitoring.
9. Pseudogout: patient has a history of pseudogout, which may require treatment and monitoring.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's septic joint and bacteremia with antibiotics and source control.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's gout and pseudogout and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a recent discharge from the CCU for CHF exacerbation. She was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, hypoxia, and a septic shoulder joint (MRSA). The patient has undergone several interventions, including central cordis placement, aspiration of the left shoulder joint, and placement of a PICC line.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypotension: The patient requires pressor support with dopamine to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion. The etiology of hypotension is likely multifactorial, including sepsis, cardiogenic shock, and possible hypovolemia.
2. Septic joint: The patient has a positive blood culture for GPC, likely MRSA, and has undergone aspiration of the left shoulder joint. Orthopedic procedures are planned for today, including arthroscopy of the left shoulder, right MCP, and left hip.
3. Bacteremia: The patient has OSH blood cultures positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA, with a likely source of septic glenohumeral joint. Surveillance cultures will be continued daily until negative.
4. Coronaries: The patient has a history of CAD with right dominant system, mild instent re-stenois of the LAD BM stent, and occluded RCA. There is no evidence of ischemic event precipitating cardiogenic shock.
5. Pump: The patient has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy with an EF of 10%, s/p BiV ICD. She is currently autodiuresing and requires strict I/O management with aggressive diuresis as tolerated by BP.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently extubated and maintaining adequate saturation on RA. Respiratory failure is likely secondary to mucus plugging and underlying CHF.
7. Rhythm: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, s/p BiV ICD, and is currently paced. Intra-atrial thrombus was noted on TEE, and she is receiving heparin gtt.
8. Acute on CRF: The patient has a baseline Cr of 1.3-1.8, which increased to 2.4 on presentation. This is likely related to CHF.
9. H/o DVT/PE: The patient has a history of DVT/PE and is currently on heparin gtt with a filter in place. Her INR has improved to therapeutic range of 2.8.
10. Hypothyroidism: The patient is taking Levothyroxine.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's EF is 10%, and she has a history of cardiomyopathy, which increases her risk of cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a septic shoulder joint and bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has underlying CHF and may experience respiratory failure due to mucus plugging or other causes.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a history of CKD and has experienced acute worsening of renal function, which can lead to renal failure.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin gtt and has a history of DVT/PE, which increases her risk of bleeding complications.
6. Infection: The patient has a septic shoulder joint and bacteremia, which can lead to infection and organ dysfunction.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently paced, which increases her risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which can lead to fatigue, weakness, and other systemic symptoms.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and interventions. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent potential complications and optimize her care.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 71-year-old female with a history of cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a past history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the cardiac care unit (CCU) for a CHF exacerbation caused by a C. difficile infection. She was readmitted to the ICU due to septic shock, hypoxia, and septic joint infection (MRSA) in the left shoulder, left hip, and right MCP.

The patient underwent a left shoulder and MCP washout/aspiration procedure on [**2179-11-25**] and is currently extubated. She is receiving dopamine for hypotension, lasix for fluid management, and vancomycin for antibiotic treatment.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6Â°C (97.8Â°F), heart rate of 71 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 76/47 mmHg. Her respiratory status is also stable, with an SpO2 of 97% on nasal cannula oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 7.1-8.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 11.0-12.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 184-234 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1-1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 27-31 mg/dL
* Glucose: 114-165 mg/dL

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. She was recently discharged from the coronary care unit (CCU) for a cardiac exacerbation and was readmitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to septic shock, hypoxia, and bacteremia.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, requiring pressor support with dopamine. The etiology is likely multifactorial, including sepsis, cardiogenic shock, and hypovolemia.
* Septic joint: The patient has a positive culture for Staphylococcus aureus in her left shoulder, left hip, and right metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. She underwent washout and aspiration of her left hip and MCP joints.
* Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for GPC in clusters/pairs, likely MRSA, with a likely source of septic glenohumeral joint. There is no evidence of endocarditis on TEE, but atrial thrombus may be infected.
* Coronaries: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease with a right dominant system, mild in-stent restenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, and occluded right coronary artery (RCA).
* Pump: The patient's ejection fraction is 10%, and she has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and a BiV ICD.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is currently extubated and is maintaining adequate saturation on nasal cannula (NC). She has a likely degree of pulmonary edema from hypervolemia.
* Rhythm: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is paced. She has an intra-atrial thrombus on TEE and is on amiodarone for antiarrhythmic and heparin gtt for anticoagulation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further septic shock and bacteremia
* Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory failure and pulmonary edema
* Renal failure and electrolyte imbalances
* Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
* Infection and sepsis related to the central line and other invasive devices
* Cardiac tamponade and pericarditis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Pressor support with dopamine to maintain adequate blood pressure
* Antibiotics for septic joint and bacteremia
* Source control with washout and aspiration of septic joints
* Anticoagulation with heparin gtt and consideration for further surgical intervention
* Management of cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrhythmias
* Respiratory support with nasal cannula and consideration for intubation
* Renal support with diuresis and electrolyte management
* Close monitoring of cardiac function and rhythm

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.
